name: Virtualization & VMs
description: Sub-sector template for virtualization patents (CPC G06F9/45*) including hypervisors, VMs, containers, and cloud orchestration.
contextDescription: Virtualization patents cover the core technologies enabling cloud computing. G06F9/455 covers virtual machine management, G06F9/45533 covers VM migration, G06F9/45558 covers hypervisor technologies. Key targets include VMware, Microsoft Hyper-V, AWS EC2, Google Cloud, Oracle VM, and container platforms (Docker, Kubernetes). These patents often command high royalties due to per-instance licensing.
scoringGuidance: Hypervisor-level patents have the broadest infringement scope in virtualization.
Live migration patents (G06F9/45533) are critical for cloud elasticity and high availability.
Container/namespace patents may overlap with VM patents in hybrid environments.
Hardware-assisted virtualization patents (VT-x, AMD-V) read on all modern processors.
Multi-tenancy isolation patents are essential for public cloud security.

questions.question: Does this patent cover hypervisor-level functionality, VM management, or guest OS behavior? Score: 1-3 for guest-only, 4-6 for VMM/hypervisor, 7-10 for Type-1 hypervisor or hardware-level.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Hypervisor patents have broadest scope. Identify the virtualization layer.

questions.question: Does this patent address live VM migration, memory ballooning, or workload mobility? Essential for cloud elasticity.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Live migration is used constantly in cloud environments.

questions.question: Does this patent apply to container technologies (Docker, Kubernetes, LXC)? Containers are the dominant deployment model.
questions.reasoningPrompt: Containers have overtaken VMs for many workloads. Assess container applicability.

questions.question: Which major cloud vendors likely implement this? Score based on breadth: 1-3 for niche, 4-6 for 1-2 major vendors, 7-10 for all major clouds (AWS, Azure, GCP).
questions.reasoningPrompt: Identify specific cloud platforms that would use this technology.
